commentary.para: Pie charts are used to show percentages of parts of a whole piece of data.
Below is the framework that was used to create this report.
In order to plan the report, the writer decides what to cover in each paragraph and takes notes.
Look at the two charts separately and report on the proportions spent in the main categories by each family.
Compare the two charts and report on the differences in expenditure between the two families.
The writer uses key words and phrases for reporting on data.

checklist.point: Examine the data you are reporting on and make notes.
Ask yourself questions about what the charts show.
Organize the information so that you highlight the most interesting differences.
Use language that is plain and simple, but academic in style.
Use language to describe general features.
Use language to describe proportions of a whole.
Use language to describe differences between amounts.
Compare the proportions shown on each chart.
Have I introduced the subject of the data?
Have I made some interesting comparisons and contrasts?
Have I reported the data accurately?
Does the conclusion summarize the data?
Have I checked vocabulary, grammar and spelling?

content.para: Summarize the information in the pie charts by selecting and reporting the main features and make comparisons.

paragraph.name: Introduction
paragraph.desc: Describe the subject of the data.

notes.para: Charts: average monthly expenditure of 2 families

content.para: The two pie charts illustrate the average monthly expenditure of two families.

paragraph.name: Comparison
paragraph.desc: Compare the most significant categories in the charts.

notes.para: Family A: biggest expenditure each month—twice what they spend on entertainment; spend much more on bills—about a quarter of their budget; spend less on entertainment; food slightly higher than entertainment; bills other large item—14%
Family B: mortgage is less—about quarter of their budget; spend much more on bills than Family A.

content.para: The mortgage is a significant item of expenditure for both families, Family A spending more on their mortgage than they do on anything else (32% of their budget). This is exactly twice what they spend on entertainment each month. Their food budget is slightly higher at just under 20%. Bills form the other large item of expenditure at 14% of their monthly budget. Family B, on the other hand, spend considerably more on their bills, but this is compensated for by their mortgage, which is approximately a quarter of their budget and 8% less than Family A's.

paragraph.name: Further comparison
paragraph.tip: TIP Depending on the amount of data you are writing about, you may need more than two paragraphs to compare the charts.

notes.para: Car: Family B—spend 14%. Family A spend less.
Clothes: similar, but Family A spend slightly more.
Entertainment: Family B spend less than Family A.

content.para: Both families spend similar amounts on their car and clothes combined, (19% for Family A and 17% for Family B), although Family B spends a larger amount on their car. Family B also spend significantly less on entertainment than Family A (9% as opposed to 16%).

paragraph.name: Conclusion
paragraph.desc: Summarize the information in the charts with a general conclusion.

notes.para: Family B spend more on necessities (bills, food and car).
Family A spend more on entertainment and clothes.

content.para: While the mortgage is the most important item of expenditure for both families, in general Family B spend more than A on necessary items, such as bills, food and their car, while Family A allow slightly more money for entertainment and clothes.
